I really appreciated your reliability and punctuality, even though you can be kind of a pain.But, my dear Aunt Flo, things have changed now. I think we need some time apart. You are no longer welcome. Please go away and do not come back for about 40 weeks. I would like that very much. Oh, and next time you visit, you had better have a baby with you. I want a god damn baby. Teenagers make it look so easy! Poo.Sincerely,Rachel H.******************************************************************************I went to Mel-O-Dee feeling sort of bummed and irritable. When Aunt Flo visits it means I can drink again, and alcohol makes me feel better when I am bummed. So does karaoke. Mel-O-Dee's hurricanes DID make me feel better, and so did the company (Emily J., Jac. C., Debbie L., Jason C., my husband, and my parents). My friends and family are super. Five stars for them and the drinks.The karaoke did not make me feel better. The KJ does not run karaoke anywhere near as well as DoowopBob (http://www.yelp.com/biz/doowopbob---karaoke-dj-concord) from my favorite karaoke bar, The Captain's Chest (http://www.yelp.com/biz/captains-chest-cocktail-lounge-concord#hrid:K05hy5Ewinl6a121r8ZFXQ). DoowopBob is fair, has a rotation, and everyone gets one turn per round. The KJ here stinks. There were some people who got to sing three times before I got to sing my second song, and it appeared it was because they know the KJ. How unprofessional. He also doesn't adjust the sound for each singer. Some people's voices were amplified too loud, while other singers could barely be heard because the backing track was too loud. He also has a very slim song selection. Negative eleventy stars for this guy. I would not go here for karaoke again, and I see no reason to drink here either when Club Mallard is so much better.The cocktail waitress was awesome! She earns this place an extra star.5 stars for waitress. 5 stars for hurricanes. 1 star for KJ. 0 stars for Aunt Flo, that whoreface.

I was torn on how many stars to give Mel-O-Dee.  The bar itself definitely deserves 4 or 5.  It is cozy, has lovely decor (velvet wallpaper!), friendly staff, inexpensive drinks, nice seating areas, and a saloon door to the bathrooms.  Fun!I had to take off a star for the karaoke.  I had a similar experience to Rachel V. and Selina B.  I love karaoke and was excited to try a new karaoke place.  They don't have a huge song selection but that is okay with me.  The karaoke guy came around and got our song slips, along with a number of other people's.  He started going through the list.  I noticed immediately that he was not adjusting the music tracks for people.  A woman got up who had a lovely voice but we could barely hear her over the backing track.  The KJ didn't seem to notice. We sang our songs and then turned in our second slips.  Three people who had sung right before us during the first round were called up a second time so we assumed we were almost up.  Then a bunch of new singers were called up. Then one of the men who was right before us was called up for a third time.  At this point I realized that we probably weren't going to singing again.  I am fine with only singing once when a place is really busy but it seemed like people who knew the KJ were given priority and allowed to sing multiple songs before others had an opportunity. I have never expected that treatment at my regular karaoke place and was disappointed that they do it like that here. I really liked the bar and would go back...just not for karaoke.

This place is well hidden! It has a very unique feeling to it and friendly bartender! If you are a P.B.R (Paps Blue Ribbon) drinker, they have it on tap for $2.50! I went with a few coworkers on a Thursday night and well it just happened to be ladies night and everything is a dollar cheaper~ it was a great night! it is your typical "hole in the wall" bar and it does have a full bar and does have a pretty good selection of top shelf and lower shelf. They have a tequila dispenser that keeps it cold and ready for when you want that shot. Plus I really love saying the name Mel-o-deeeeeeeeeeeee!

This was suppose to be my entourage's "hole in the wall" but apparently a trend has occurred to start coming here. One trip my fiancé and I took here we ended up waiting a full hour for one song and when I asked the bartender for the drinks I had on my first visit she told me that only one bartender does those "cheap cocktail" specials and he only works on Tuesdays. I assured her I came during the weekend and she adamantly suggested that I mixed up my weekdays and weekends - I might really enjoy my weekends but not enough to be convinced that I was displaced in some time-space parallel and Friday or Saturday was actually Tuesday!! I ended up getting a watered down, over-priced drink which has deterred me from ordering here (I'll just get some Clubs at Safeway, thanks).The most recent trip back was with my full force entourage but still we made little impact in the karaoke line - 30 minutes before my fiancé got to sing and my friend and I never got to do our "You Ought to Know", "Basketcase", or our closer of "Tubthumping". The only deliciously fun moment was when someone from another party sang "Time Warp" (which I had done on my last visit and no one had the balls/ovaries/other miscellaneous parts to dance to it) and the crowd actually joined in - I think he may have been in the musical previously (for those of you looking - "Barely Legal" in Oakland).I lay to rest my memories of this place. I once loved you Mel-O-Dee but I don't think I'll be back until you get another machine or learn that allowing certain singers to go more times than the rest of the crowd during "rounds" only annoys customers; and you get bartenders who are conscious of a patron with money in their hand who wants drinks in his/her belly. You were cute Mel but I'll be back when your ego is deflated and you remember why you were cool in the first place.

Well worth another star. New comfortable chairs, new carpet and same great ,friendly serving staff. Karaoke going strong as are the drinks, which during happy hour they practically give away. Oh, they just put in a new huge screen tv in time for the Super Bowl. All this and it's still a dive. Well done folks.

Went for my birthday. They have Pabst on Tap now, yeshhhh. And of course drinks are still super cheap.Now onto the karaoke... It was a busy night, I'll give them that. I think I was one of three parties there celebrating birthdays so I didn't get to sing until the very end of the night. Which is fine. BUT, there were people who sang multiple times before me. (one lady friend of the DJ sang 4 times). Also, my initial song request had apparently already been requested by someone else before me and I didn't know this until I heard them singing it. The DJ never told me anything when I submitted the song and when I went up there to give him another song he was was unaware of this issue. The same thing happened for two other people in my party and they were told that they can sing the same song as well and didn't need to put in another. That is SO against the karaoke rules!There are rules aren't there?!

Got invited here to celebrate a friend's birthday on karaoke night, and had a BLAST! We had SO much fun, in fact, that we made a point to get together to do again (which happened last night), and now we're thinking of coming regularly! I've even recruited more people to join us, they're hooked after one visit =PThe bar:An awesome, unpretentious, no drama, no fuss no muss kind of place. Cheap strong drinks made by friendly and pleasant bartenders, ultra-retro fun decor (walls have velvet wallpaper and mirrors, and there's a western-y swinging door to get to the bathroom area). Dive-y and comfortable, nobody passing judgment here! And there's one crazy regular, this older guy, who makes everybody feel good by going around, telling stories, giving compliments, dancing, shaking hands, and laughing at everything, hahaha. Last night there was even someone's dog wandering around? Very cute, friendly, and didn't seem to mind the loud music, which tells me he probably comes around pretty often. Anything goes!The karaoke:Everyone could get up and sing whatever they wanted and were sure to be supported no matter what the talent level :) To get the atmosphere right, there's a  light-up microphone, disco ball, fog machine, and small dance floor XD The song list is limited (which is why 4 stars instead of 5), mostly 80's hits, classic country, and the old standards, but there are a few surprising songs on the list that I wouldn't have expected to see! Besides, those oldies are what really get a crowd going, because everyone knows them, loves them, and sings along!All in all, I recommend this place to just about anyone, because everyone's welcomed here! Expand the song list and they get my 5 stars :)

I wish there were more old school bars like this in SF.It's definitely a come-as-you-are, neighborhood kind of place.  No drama, no "scene," and I'd totally feel comfortable wearing sweats and a T-shirt. Just regular people, a little karaoke action (and it really doesn't matter how bad you are, so's the sound system and the playlist) and the occaisional drink special.  The velvet wallpaper and saloon-style doors to the bathrooms add to the feel of the place.As another reviewer mentioned it's a little difficult to find, but on the plus side I got an unexpected tour of El Cerrito Plaza.I don't see myself making the trek often, but given a good reason I'd definitely do it again.

Leaving BART and walking to the El Cerrito Plaza, you have to walk around the whole plaza to find Mel-O-Dee ... but it's worth it.The decor has not changed since the early 70s but it is so warm and cozy. My family had the same swivel chairs in our kitchen from that time period maybe that is why. I could have sat there all night drinking ... wait, I did.There was a special drink that night because it was so hot. For $4 it was worth it, juice and rum and Midori. When she ran out of Midori, she made us another special, the "Rum Runner" which was equally as good and was welcomed on such a hot night. The bartender was very personable and was quick and efficient.Karaoke was fun but I didn't sing because they did not have The Cure, Beastie Boys, or "Tainted Love". After not finding songs I liked, I became disenchanted and resolved myself to chair dancing and singing which was pretty fun in itself.Would I come back -- YES. Would I bring my friends -- YES. If I lived near El Cerrito BART, I would make Mel-O-Dee my local.

[Update 9/2008]: I went back recently and things are still good at Mel-o-Dee, but there has been a little change.  I like the new KJ.  However the fun lights were not there anymore (the KJ tried to compensate with a couple of trinkets, but I am hoping they plan to upgrade the stage lights--they were not elaborate to start with but they did make it more fun).  Second, the EQ on the microphone (or the quality of the microphone, I am not sure which), needed adjusting--the mic did not project enough presence in the voice.  Third, the song selection needs a fair amount of improvement, but I still found more than enough.  These are small criticisms, because the place is still great and I had a great time.

I came here for my very first East Bay DYL last week!  I frequent the El Cerrito Plaza, yet have never stepped into Mel-O-Dee before.  I actually kind of didn't even know that it existed as a bar; I've always thought that it was part of The Junket next door for some reason, but alas, it is not.  It's easy to not notice this place because it's pretty narrow and windowless, and their name painted on the wall isn't very flashy, so I was pleasantly surprised to find a cool Western saloon-esque bar when I stepped in.When I asked my fellow Yelpers, "What's good here?", everyone raised up their fruity looking drinks and unanimously said, "The Hurricane".  So The Hurricane it was.  The kind, lovely bartendress concocted an awesome drink for me.  All I recognized was the pineapple juice and the Midori mix.  Anything with pineapple and Midori is good in my book.  And it was only $4 since it was the special of the night.  Suh-weet!I adore the decor of this place.  Fire-engine red velvet walls.  Lovely dark wood beams.  Swinging saloon doors.  And I fell in love with their boudoir-esque bathroom!And the icing on the cake has got to be their location.  In the middle of the DYL, I walked a couple of stores down to Trader Joe's, did some grocery shopping right before they closed, and then walked back to Mel-O-Dee to get my drinkage back on within 15 minutes.  So convenient!

"We went in and no one was there.  We got scared.  So we left."I was a little afraid to go into this place when part of the EB DYL crowd greeted us with that.I think it was just the lack of lighting that scared them.  I really don't think it was the cast of Cocoon sitting at the bar. We made our way back to the latter years Elvis lounge in the back.  One magnificent, black, tufted leather couch winds the length of two walls -   complimented by small circular "club" tables and swivel chairs.  It's easy to slide in and get comfy with a lot of good friends.  It was so dark at one point, the pool players were having trouble seeing.  We tried to turn on the light over the pool table but knew instantly that it killed the mood and turned it back off.Then Angelo proceeded to make the bank shot of the year.  The KJ hoisted the table up onto a dolly and moved it aside to reveal the dance floor.He has a couple of really cool microphones, albeit the blinky light one is a little distracting when girls hold it near their bewbs.  He should have saved money on the mics and concentrated on the song book because the selections are weak at best.Give me a crappy song list and un-readable lyrics - I'magonna make an idiot of myself and probably you as well.The cute little bartender couldn't have been nicer.  I was always greeted with a "Welcome Back" when I headed back for "one more" and she always tried to talk me into getting two.  I have a fuzzy memory of her actually hiking up her skirt, she was seemingly trying to demonstrate something to one of the regulars - I kind of short circuited when she did it.  I'm not sure what it was about but it was fun.I'd go back.  If they don't improve their song selections by then, I'm threatening to throw down "The Real Slim Shady".

In case you didn't read the words to the left of this review, I grew up in Nevada.  Which means I went to the Cal-Neva to gamble cheap, had many dinners in all-you-can-eat buffets, and was assaulted by cigarette smoke constantly.  This place reminds me of Reno.  A LOT.  Partially because the red velvet flocked walls and carpet still are hanging on to years of cigarette smoke, also because of the saloon doors to the bathroom, but mostly because of the clientele.  And I'm not just talking about the peeps who were on a mission to destroy their livers, but the cool dudes at the bar. This is just a cool place where Angelo can smoke Andrew at pool, I can chat with the hotness Sara about ANTM, talk to Jenn about footwear, look at Anna's awesome stocking choice, listen to Keith talk about how he got lost in a parking lot, or watch Shelly welcome the DYL virgins.  Sadly, I missed the karaoke because I was too tired from hipping and hopping at the ho down, but not a bad place.They might want to invest in a case of Febreeze, though.

very cool spot. LOVED the velvet walls and the comfy seating. leather rolling chairs at a bar? NICE! played some pool, watched some karaoke, had some fun. the saloon bathroom entrance was cool too. bartender was super friendly and promised me that she would have little umbrella's for our beer next time. what's a beer without a straw and a mini-umbrella?

This was my first DYL event where I actually stayed more than ten minutes. East Bay DYL'ers know how to do it and they know how to do it well. The velvet walls definitely made this place unique from the rest. The drink specials were pretty reasonable and mixed pretty well.I love the Old School mic for singing karaoke. I think I'll be belting more songs out here more often. Just bring your earplugs because I'm totally tone deaf :) Don't say I didn't warn you. If they had more BritPop, I'd be all over the mic here...but then I'd probably piss off the good karaoke singers. I guess I'll stick to my guilty pleasures of old 80s hair metal (I can thank my brother for scarring me for life with the cheesiest music of the decade).Thank you to all the lovely DYL'ers for making my experience here more fun. Yeah...I was only going to stay an hour but there was lots of good conversation with cool people. So I didn't leave until almost the last BART train left. This place is totally bitchin' especially when you mix it with a bunch of awesome Yelpers. Kudos to Bill B and those awesome dance moves. heehee.

"I wanna rock and roll all night..." And the karaoke here was fun enough that I almost could. The limitation is, as mentioned, that while they have a large book of songs, it's an odd mix and missing a lot of classics. Still, there are lots of fun ones, and the small, hardwood dancefloor allows you to bust out an 80's-inspired powerslide. (Not that I would know...)Still, the 60's mood lighting, velvet wall covering, and pleather booths create a fun atmosphere that helps you not feel like the cheesiest thing in the place while you drunkenly belt out Addicted to Love. A coin-op pool table and video touch-screen games provide additional entertainment.Kelly, the bartender, was very friendly as well as quick with the drinks. My main knock against the bar is that some of the bartenders will let patrons smoke inside...and you can sometimes tell.Oh, last tip: Don't let Shelly L. catch you sitting in one of the swivel chairs. She'll try to spin you round and round until you feel ill. :)

Pros:1. What everyone else said about the interior being very nice is true. 2. The drinks are good for their prices, and the weekend karaoke is not too crowded like it is at Encore Karaoke. 3. Negligible hipster crowd4. Pretty good sound system for those sitting in the side room where the karaoke takes place5. Located in El Cerrito, which is better then being located in foggy, hard-to-drive-in San Francisco.Cons:1. Limited song selection2. Sound system does not extend into bar area, making it hard to hear singers from the bar and follow along. Most distressingly, it makes it hard to hear the KJ from the bar announce who is supposed to sing next. This is exacerbated by the fact that the KJ on Saturdays doesn't seem to enunciate very well.

I love this place. This is a REAL old school dive bar complete w/ cigarette vending machine, old comfy ass chairs, old surly bartender and the ability to smoke in the bar. I used to work at Petco and would come here every break I got, shhhhh! Drinks are nice and stiff and happy hour prices in combination with said stiff drinks make it easy to return to work or wherever you're on your way to nice and buzzed ;-]

I LOVE THIS PLACE! It is a total dive, but in the best way. The patrons are great, the bartender is awesome, the kj is good and the drinks are seriously cheap. The song selection is very limited but that is ok for those who have their own CDs or those who love 80"s classics. This place welcomes everyone and is the perfect chill bar.

Awesome bartenders. Cheap drinks. I get my dirty martinis for $4 a pop. They only take cash BUT there is an ATM a few doors down. The karaoke list needs to be updated but it's still fun. Not very many college kids here, which is a plus for me. You've got your regulars singing the same songs every week and mostly everyone knows everyone else by name. It's got a Cheers vibe to it. Oh. and the wallpaper is red and fuzzy. Excellent.

most fun karaoke spot i've ever been to beside punk rock karaoke in NYC. the people there are fun, the regulars are super nice, and you don't feel like a fool singing - how can you when people are dancing while you sing! kelly, the bartender, is amazing cool and drinks are strong - careful! i wish the song list was a little larger and a little more current, but it is still a blast, and you can bring your own cd's. ron, the karaoke MC is mellow and can come off a little intimidating at first, but he is a really good guy. the hubby and i love this place and are there a lot to get our karaoke on! good spot for karaoke fans and virgins to karaoke!

First off, the bartender had me name my cocktail "The Jessica" so that when I came up to order more, I wouldn't sound SO GODDAM LAME ordering a(nother) Malibu & Coke. For myself. Because I'm a lightweight but can drink this stuff for a hundred years and feel just skippy, that night and the next. So fug you, I like sugar drinks, moving on.It's important that the bartender did this because it speaks volumes- volume one, that she was encouraging me to drink plural sugar drinks meaning she will enable you to drink like a little fishy, or to your hearts content, whichever comes first. And volume 2, that I had a really good time there and never once wanted to punch that lady bartendress in the mouth for making fun of me. Trust me, I'm short and gamey- punching people who tease me, in the mouth, seems like a good idea especially after sugar drinks. POW!Anyway. This bar is optimal for your sight-seeing needs in the far east bay. Do you need to watch a man with probably drain bamage singing Strawberry Fields, Stairway, and Let's Go Crazy by Prince including splits on the floor?!?!?!?OH NO LET"S GO!Seriously, that and the girl who sang Father Figure with the most sincerity and intensity....what a memorable night. This is the best people watching place in all of El Cerrito Plaza.We didn't sing a goddam thing, although I threatened my bfer that I'd make him stand there while I serenaded him with I'm Your Man by Leonard Cohen, which I still think would be a funny visual, if you imagine me with a hat and maybe a tie. But they didn't have it.With the wallpaper/mirrors/tufted leather banquette.... it's like you've gone to visit gramma and she's naming drinks after you.Try The Jessica! 5 stars!

Five stars for memories. Its like a party in some ones game room.  All types of people are frequenting this place.  Word of mouth is the reason. Comfy pleather seats.  This is a place to have a group of friends talk and listen to the tunes on the juke box. I'm sad to see that there is no more pink shag carpet in the women's rest room! Original red fuzzy wall paper is still intact.  Friday nights is Karaoke.  Of course there are the bizarre performances that make you laugh, but I was surprised at the local talent.  Very good singers.  Random people will pair up for duets or serve as back up singers.  Regulars bring their own CD's and give them to the Karaoke DJ.  Very cool.

My friend gave me the 411 on this place before we went here, so I thought I was prepared for it.Think again. I forgot my singing voice AND my obnoxious drunk asshole shield. Must have been having a blond moment back in Oakland.Now, I've been to El Cerrito before so I thought I was reasonably prepared for the kind of crowd that would await me here. Once again, I was wrong. Immediately my friend and I are greeted by a lumbering drunk guy who decided to use us as crutches. "LADIES LADIES! ARE YOU BUYING YOUR OWN DRINKS TONIGHT?""Well, um....Yeah. It's just beer. It's cheap.""OH NO LADIES I WON'T HAVE THAT OH NO! HEY BARTENDER GET THESE LADIES SOME DRINK CHIPS! I WANNA BACK 'EM UP."Me, thinking "back 'em up" was some El Cerrito slang for "bang 'em up the ass" nearly fell out of my chair in anticipation - I mean fear!!!! FEAR! Anyway, this man was incredibly obnoxious and I was trying to decide the best way for us to make an escape. And honestly, there was no "best way" because the Mel-O-Dee is a pretty tiny bar. Thankfully the female bartender (didn't get her name) swooped into our rescue. Whatever it was that she said to the Jolly White Giant calmed him down, and he actually left the bar soon after. That woman is a total lifesaver and is absolutely one of my favorite bartenders ever!This place is a little weird altogether and it kinda makes me feel like I'm in that Bizarro episode of Sealab 2020. I saw a table of people that could have been myself and my friends had our lives all worked out a little differently. Everyone here was very cordial, but I didn't trust them for one minute. People that nice must have SOMETHING wrong with them.

Hands down, , , one of my favorite bars in the east bay!!!Remember that 'Sex and the City' episode where Carrie ends up at some late night Chinese restaurant with Big, runs into an old friend and later finds out this is where guys take ladies they don't want to be seen in public with? That's the Mel*O*Dee. But not really. Just seems that way.Red velvet and gold wallpaper and retro ( I shouldn't say retro since they're the real deal) booths line the perimeter of this fine establishment. The ladies WC doesn't skip a beat either, plush pink carpeting, pink wallpaper and a vanity equipped with dainty old school vanity seats.Bartenders and patrons are both as old as dirt. Live music on Fridays was always a treat. You should see these seniors all dressed up in their nightlife attire, dancing to the band (keyboards, accordion and lead singer) and living it up on a Friday night. I can only hope I have that in me when I reach their age.It's a fairly small place, but big enough for groups. I had my "going away after party" here back in 2003.It's been a while since I've been to this gem, sounds like I need to get back over there and get my karaoke on!

I stumbled in the doors of the Mel-O-Dee on one of those nights when I should have probably just hopped on BART and gone home, but instead found myself singing karoke in a room with fuzzy red and gold wallpaper.Since I live in the heart of Hipster Nation, it's really nice to take a vacation from it, so I was REALLY happy when I took around at the crowd.  It was like being in Iowa at one of those old bars along the highway that only the locals know about. Everyone is slightly off, strange but sweet, and of completely indeterminent age.My little group got 10 stars for effort and dramatic interpretation.  Just about everyone else in there got stars for actually being able to sing, and giving us standing ovations just because we were unafraid in our foolishness.The drinks were really cheap and the bartender was so sweet to us.Best part: the Mel-O-Dee is only a block away from BART and at the ass-end of a shopping center/strip mall.

Too funny! The wall paper is great. The karaoke regulars are really good and quite entertaining. Another reviewer was right that is has a David Lynch sort of feel to it. I would definitely recommend going with a few friends. It's not exactly a place where you might meet someone, but it's fun. You have to keep a sense of humor about it. It's an old bar that is not trying to impress anyone!

If you like a dive bar when its not karaoke night or if you would like to celebrate your birthday by acting like you know the words to "Purple Rain" by PRINCE, then this is the bar for you.Don't go in there thinking that you're gonna have an "off-the-hook" time. Don't go in there asking for a "incredible hulk" or latest "crunk drink" because the bartender will not know it and wont even think about making it for you. This is strictly an old schoolers bar with a little karaoke in there. You might see the youngsters in there every now and then but this is a good bar for the experienced bar-hoppers, divers, middle aged and older crowd.Don't expect dope ass night at this place. Ain't gonna happen unless you already got this night planned out with your friends or loved ones. But that's not to say that you won't have a good time at all. In fact, i crashed some girls birthday party there one night by accident. My friends and i were the life of the party, even taking pictures with the unknown birthday girl and doing a karaoke duet with her! Now my friends and I are the official birthday crashers. lolSo anyway, if you dig on somewhat cheap drinks, karaoke machine, crashing someones birthday, meeting old-timers and some newbies then this would be the bar for you. I gave it 2 stars because the last time i was there it was boo-boo. However, i would recommend this bar to someone when it's on a good night of karoke fun.And that's my review. Thanks for reading. Word.

What the *@&!?  Here are the reasons we love the Mel-o-dee:*Karaoke*Not a window in the place*Crushed Velvet Wall Paper*Spot Lotto is available*3 stiff drinks = $9!*People dancing to karaoke*15 minute wait for a hot girl like Vivian to get a drink*20 song selection from Merle Haggard (??)*Total sausage fest*The regulars are SUPER friendlyYou know it's a good time when you hear someone sing Elton John's classic song "Don't let your son go down on me" and when Jay H tells you your boobs aren't that special. Oh, by the way, did I mention we had a few drinks there?

So, say you're on the verge of a serious breakdown because you've had TWO G-D DAYS OFF THIS ENTIRE EFFING CALENDAR YEAR...  And say, you feel like you're constantly robbing Peter to pay Paul (whatever the hell that means) whenever you need a minute or two off because you're so damn busy that all kinds of "life" things fall to the wayside (you know, like dishes, laundry, friends etc).  And say you have a Friday night meeting for work that's supposed to run until 7pm and that actually thrills you to death because it means that your Friday actually ends at 7pm and you might actually get to see your beloved friends for the first time in a long while on a Friday night, when the rest of the world is out partying and usually, you are still working....  And then, say, two of your best friends are also having "verge of a serious breakdown" days and they also want to see you so the three of you can get together and do what BFFs do--get trashed, bitch about our lives, sing drunken karaoke in El Cerrito, and then make someone's boyfriend come pick us up.  Where do you go?  To Mel-O-Dee, suckers!  Crushed velvet wall paper, old fashioned cash register, song list straight out of 1988, and the nicest regulars ever.  Seriously.  This place is completely "scene"-less and a complete gem.

Aw shit!! I've discovered ANOTHER place to sing Karaoke!Honestly the world cannot have enough Karaoke bars for me.This has to be one of the best though!  The drinks are strong and cheap!  The wall paper alone is reason to love this place!  I swear my grandmother had a couch that had the same material on it.   The regulars are friendly and the most fun group of people I have ever met at a bar.  Where else do you go up to sing and the bar patrons begin to dance?  Dancing to Karaoke!!!  If you really wanna feel like a super star you gotta karaoke here!  They need hella more songs for their book though.

I am updating my review of this place.  I used to be a diehard regular and bring all kinds of friends here.  Sadly I have boycotted Mel O' Dee's for well over a year now.  First they fired the KJ who might have been a bit slow, but he had the best sound in the East Bay and most of SF and was a nice guy.  The replacement had poor sound quality.  Then they insulted me for letting them know what I thought when they asked me to put a note in thier comment box.  And from what I hear through the rumor mill, the unfairness on the list is super obvious and biased toward one person.  It's a shame because it it close to me and a cozy hangout.  I guess the old saying is true, what goes up must come down.  And down it went.Luckily there are plenty of fine karaoke joints in San Francisco, and I might say worth the drive and toll.  I have met many fine people and had great experiences branching out.  VIVA KARAOKE (just not here).

Hey you wanna go for a drink at the Mel-o-dee? No thanks. No thanks? What does that mean? I don't wanna go. Go where? For a drink at the mel-o-dee. A drink at the mel-o-dee! Now that's a good idea!come for the cheap booze, stay for the womb-like crushed velvet walls, plasti-gold coated circa 1978 light fixtures, and the most bizarre and spirited karaoke in the B-east, period.Hello, baby.Shut up! It's Daddy, you shithead! Where's my bourbon?

Luckily, there isn't really a need to try and impart to you the obscene cred of the Mel-O-Dee, because Wes Anderson and Sofia Coppola have basically already done that, but suffice it to say, it's like a David Lynch movie about a party in your pants. In Nevada. Or rather, El Cerrito. Same thing. Whatever.The wallpaper in here will blow your mind it's so fucking awesome (I think they actually rebuilt the El Cerrito Plaza around the walls of this place to avoid fucking with all the gilt and felted red brocade.)  And, the ladies' powder room is straight fresh, second only in fabulousness to the powder room at the First Congregational Church in Oakland.  Five stars.

how to describe the perfect place? you simply can not. just know that you have not lived until you see maria d grabbing the microphone from some inebriated frat boy to join megan w in a duet of belinda carlisle's, "heaven is a place on earth". or until you see megan w getting DOWN to taylor dayne.  or joy m doing a perfect rendition (cockney accent and all) of "consider yourself" from oliver.  or brigid c. fucking owning randy newman's, "short people".  or maria d. doing a PITCH PERFECT RENDITION of the scorpion's, "rock you like a hurricane".  i was rocked.  i think the whole crowd was.  what i'm saying is we were at a rockin' party last night at mel-o-dee and you were not. jealous? i know so. i, myself, plan on being here every friday and/or saturday (kareoke two nights in a row, fool!  every weekend!) night for the next ten years. p.s. i am tired and totally just marked the majority of this review from maria d.  i am a tool.  a really fucking hot tool.p.p.s. they also have the most perfect wall paper ever here.  i can't even begin to describe it because i want your mind to be sufficiently blown when you see it and also, the words i want to use don't exist in the english language.  it's.  fucking.  amazing.HAPPY BIRTHDAY, BRIGID SUZANNE!!!!  I LOVE YOU!!!!

how to describe the perfect place? you simply can not. just know that you have not lived until you see laura b doing the macarena with a 65 year old man in a sailor's cap. or until you see megan w dancing to james brown. or joy m doing a perfect rendition (cockney accent and all) of "consider yourself" from oliver. or joy m and laura b dedicating "9-5" to the memory of anna nicole smith. what i'm saying is we were at a rockin' party last night at mel-o-dee and you were not. jealous? i hope so.

This place can cure a bad mood not only with strong, cheap drinks, but warm, fuzzy feelings inspired by the comraderie of the faithful regulars, strong enough to penetrate even the snobbiest hipster veneer.  There is no pressure to be Cool here at the Mel-O-Dee in El Cerrito Plaza, which feels more like the heart of some Vegas backroad.  Everyone sings and dances with abandon, talented or not (and there are both).  It's clear that karaoke night is both cathartic and exciting in that special moment-to-shine way for everyone who gets up and sings.  And my god, the wallpaper!  It's red, fuzzy, and beautiful, like a fake velvet rose you find in your grandmother's house, next to the whiskey and old letters from a secret lover.

You walk in and see velvety red and gold wallpaper, an old cigarette machine, a disco ball, and a pool table.  No, you are not in some seedy little bar in some redneck town.  You, my friend, are in El Cerrito.  Actually, you are in the El Cerrito Plaza, a little strip mall.  Sandwiched in between Petco and Trader Joe's is a delightful little bar called the Mel-O-Dee.  Yes, there are a lot of retired folk that are regulars there, but on the weekends it can be pretty mixed.  On Friday and Saturday nights they move the pool table out of the way and have karaoke and dancing.  If you are lucky, the guy that does a seriously kick ass Otis Redding will be singing.  He is a treasure.

OLD.  It looks twice as old as the strip mall in which it's located.  The people at the bar look like they've been sitting there since the wallpaper was put up in 1320.  But everyone is nice!  And Karaoke is hilarious; because they are good!I asked myself, "What the fuck am I doing out of SF and in a bar in El Cerrito?  I'm at the Mel-O-Dee!"

"The bar that time forgot" ... according to the bartender, an older lady who is always smiling as she pours you amazingly cheap and strong drinks, the place has barely changed since it opened in 1969.  With the exception of the removal of the adorable pink carpet in the lady's room.  :-(  It's tucked between a deli and PetCo in the El Cerrito Plaza shopping center ... weirdest place for the coolest bar ever.  The gold and red velvet wallpaper is really something to see.On karaoke nights (Fri & Sat), there are always a few groups of hipsters celebrating a birthday battling for the microphone with the regulars, some of whom sing like pros.  You'll see this old black dude who always sings Otis Redding boogeying down on the dance floor with a 22-year-old tattooed white chick, a middle-aged Philipino lady ("I Will Survive" is her song of choice) shakin it in the center of a group of indie rocker kids.  It's amazing.  I've never seen this happen anywhere else.  I took my friend there for her birthday, without calling ahead or anything, and the propietors put "Happy Birthday Anna!" on the karaoke monitors.  It's so hard to leave, because you always want to see what the next song will be.  Go there this weekend.

Shaky hands down, this is one of my favorite bars in California. This is definitely an old folk's hangout, which actually seals the deal for me. You won't find yourself screaming over the jukebox here, and I don't think a fight has erupted in the place since 1968. However, there's always a retired cop in the place, so maybe smoking pot out in the parking lot isn't the wisest idea...unless you know him by name and don't puke anywhere (Michael!).  The drinks are poured as if the friendly bartender wants to see if you can handle your booze, so you definitely get more bang for you buck here. Just don't order any cocktail involving coca cola, as the tap is usually flat. The walls are covered in red, velvet wallpaper and the entire back room is littered with black, vinyl booths and chairs.  If you've ever longed to belt out some karaoke to a room full of clapping pensioners, this shoudl be your friday night spot.

Oh, the Mel-O-Dee...it's a sleepy little joint in the mall during the day, but it comes to life at night with an upbeat flock of regulars.  The big back room has gaudy-cool red and gold wallpaper and the black leather booths and chairs are still in great shape.  The ladies' room has pink carpet!  This isn't the place to get shitfaced or have a big, loud party; it's nice for smaller, quieter gatherings over strong but cheap drinks.  There is karaoke on Saturday nights; they used to have a jazz band and dancing on Fridays, but I don't know if it's still going on.  Conveniently located mere 5 minutes from the El Cerrito Plaza BART station, there's plenty of parking at the mall in the evening, and if you need cash, there is a bank across the parking lot.  Definitely, a treasure buried amongst the vapid mall culture.
